general: Ceftaroline is a parenteral advanced-generation cephalosporin with avid binding to penicillin binding protein (PBP) 2a. Hence, Ceftaroline is active against MRSA and MRSE. Activity against enterococci is poor to moderate.
Skin and skin structure infections due to certain susceptible gram-positive and gram-negative microbes, including MRSA.
An alternative antibiotic for drug resistant genotypes.
Active in vitro vs. HVISA, VISA, and VRSA.
Ceftaroline is inactivated by AmpC and extended-spectrum beta-lactamases (ESBLs).
Aerobic gram-negative bacilli are generally susceptible with the exception of P. aeruginosa. In vitro pattern of susceptibility of aerobic gram-negative bacilli is similar to Ceftriaxone.
For cross-allergenicity, see Drug Allergy: Penicillins, Cephalosporins, Overview.

adult_dose.skin_skin_structure_infection_approved_d: 600 mg IV (over 5-60 min) q12h x5-14 days
adult_dose.cap_approved_dose: 600 mg IV (over 5-60 min) q12h x5-7 days

renal_adjustment.crcl_or_egfr: CrCl >50: No dosage adjustment. CrCl 30-50: 400 mg q12h. CrCl 15-30: 300 mg q12h. CrCl <15: 200 mg q12h
renal_adjustment.crrt: 70 kg pt, effluent flow rate 3 L/hr: 400 mg q12h 2

other_adjustment: ECMO: See ECMO Drug Dosing Adjustment.
adverse_effects: As for all cephalosporins, there is risk of allergic reaction or development of C. difficile colitis.
Positive Coomb's test in 9.8% of patients without clinical hemolysis.
Case report of eosinophilic pneumonia (Am J Health Syst Pharm 2014;71:403).
Retrospective study found reversible neutropenia in 21% of patients treated for ≥3 weeks (J Antimicrob Chemother 2016;71: 2010).

pregnancy_risk.fda_risk_category: No evidence of toxicity in humans or animals
pregnancy_risk.lactation: No data, but adverse effects not expected. Monitor infant for GI toxicity.
pregnancy_risk.footnote: Capital letter = Old FDA risk category; Text = New FDA risk category
